awd_titl_txt: The Weighted Bootstrap and Berry-Esseen Bounds in High Dimensions
awd_abstract_narration:
Resampling methods are widely used for statistical inference in numerous applications. In particular, bootstrapping is known to perform well in situations when the amount of available data is rather small. In many modern applications the data are complex and high-dimensional, motivating development of new approaches in statistical inference, including resampling methods. In this project, the investigator will study weighted bootstrap procedures in a high-dimensional framework with a limited amount of data, for various classes of statistical models. The main goals of this research are to understand essential properties of the weighted bootstrap, such as its limitations and accuracy, and to advance resampling methods in high-dimensional settings.

In this project, the investigator will study the problem of approximation in distribution of a function of a sample average in a high-dimensional non-asymptotic framework, for various classes of functions. Two basic types of approximations, which are closely related to each other, will be studied: an approximation using the weighted bootstrap procedure, and Berry-Esseen type inequalities. In both cases, the investigator aims to establish higher-order approximation bounds that extend classical Gaussian approximation theory and yield considerable improvements in accuracy with respect to both dimension and sample size. The study will be focused on optimality of the resulting bounds, and on explicit form of the error terms. Another important direction of the research in this project is extension of the proposed higher-order approximation methodology to the case of heavy-tailed distributions, which play an important role in many applications in finance and engineering. The work on the project aims to employ and further develop various modern techniques, such as higher-order approximation and comparison inequalities, concentration inequalities for multilinear symmetric forms, geometric properties of Gaussian measures in high dimensions, and methods related to multivariate moment problems.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Mathematical and Physical Sciences

por.por_cntn:
This project has been motivated by contemporary problems that arise in various applied disciplines and involve analysis of complex data sets. The major results of the project are concerned with the following topics: (i) a study of higher-order properties of resampling procedures in a high-dimensional framework and development of theoretical methods for analyzing accuracy of these procedures, (ii) a construction of efficient estimators and bias reduction in problems of functional estimation for high-dimensional and infinite-dimensional models using the bootstrap-chain method.

Resampling or bootstrapping methods are widely used by practitioners working with complex statistical models and in the situations when an amount of available data is rather small. Furthermore, it is known that the bootstrap can outperform normal approximation, which, in turn, is one of the major tools in statistical inference. The outcomes of this project include first theoretical results that quantify higher-order accuracy of the bootstrap procedures in a high-dimensional (or a multivariate) and finite sample framework. The PI developed new techniques that allow to derive explicit and optimal results about accuracy of the bootstrap and normal approximation under very general conditions. Furthermore, in a high complexity setting, the new approach leads to sharp theoretical guarantees for a number of important statistical estimation procedures.

The problem of efficient estimation of functionals of high-dimensional parameters of statistical models is very general; it is important in a variety of applications including functional data analysis and kernel machine learning, although there exist very few general approaches to address it. In this project, the PI studied and further developed special bootstrap-chain procedures that lead to bias reduction and construction of optimal estimators in a variety of high-dimensional and infinite-dimensional models under rather general conditions.

The PI served as a mentor of (under)graduate students from underrepresented minorities and developed educational materials for students of the graduate statistics program at Georgia Tech. A part of the theoretical developments obtained in this project was incorporated in the curriculum of (under)graduate level courses. The results of the project have been presented to communities of interest through talks at conferences and seminars, as well as journal publications and online preprints. The PI was also involved in organizing seminars and a workshop in research areas relevant to the project.
